contentfulBlogPost.title: What Is a Probable Case of COVID-19?

childMarkdownRemark.html: Erin Kissane is a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the project’s managing editor.
Quang P. Nguyen is a PhD candidate in the Department of Epidemiology at Dartmouth College.

description.description: The COVID Tracking Project collects and publishes the most complete testing data available for US states and territories.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Madhavi Bharadwaj is a data driven creative thinker and lifelong learner who is passionate about healthcare and public health.
Lauran Hazan is a product management leader with a minor data obsession. Currently in the Boston area on a new startup adventure.
Kara Schechtman is Data Quality Co-Lead for The COVID Tracking Project.

Sara Simon works on The COVID Tracking Project’s data quality team and is also a contributing writer. She most recently worked as an investigative data reporter at Spotlight PA and software engineer at The New York Times.

blog_post.title: How Probable Cases Changed Through the COVID-19 Pandemic

lede.lede: When analyzing COVID-19 data, confirmed case counts are obvious to study. But don’t overlook probable cases—and the varying, evolving ways that states have defined them.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Jonathan Gilmour is a Data Infrastructure engineer and Data Quality contributor at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: 20,000 Hours of Data Entry: Why We Didn’t Automate Our Data Collection

lede.lede: Looking back on a year of collecting COVID-19 data, here’s a summary of the tools we automated to make our data entry smoother and why we ultimately relied on manual data collection.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Kara Schechtman is Data Quality Co-Lead for The COVID Tracking Project.

Sara Simon works on The COVID Tracking Project’s data quality team and is also a contributing writer. She most recently worked as an investigative data reporter at Spotlight PA and software engineer at The New York Times.

blog_post.title: A Wrap-Up: The Five Major Metrics of COVID-19 Data

lede.lede: As The COVID Tracking Project comes to a close, here’s a summary of how states reported data on the five major COVID-19 metrics we tracked—tests, cases, deaths, hospitalizations, and recoveries—and how reporting complexities shaped the data.

childMarkdownRemark.html: The COVID Tracking Project is a volunteer organization launched from The Atlantic and dedicated to collecting and publishing the data required to understand the COVID-19 outbreak in the United States.

blog_post.title: Releasing Our State COVID-19 Data Log

lede.lede: From July 2020 to March 2021, The COVID Tracking Project compiled a detailed set of structured COVID-19 data notes, both on changes states made to the data and changes we made to the data we captured from states. Today, we’re releasing those notes.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Hannah Hoffman is a data entry and data quality shift lead at The COVID Tracking Project and a student in the Washington, DC area.

blog_post.title: How We Entered COVID-19 Testing and Outcomes Data Every Day for a Year

lede.lede: We set up a set of roles and a shift system to carefully gather and inspect the data we published.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Kara Schechtman is Data Quality Co-Lead for The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Federal COVID-19 Testing Data Is Getting Better

lede.lede: The federal government improved its state and county-level COVID-19 PCR testing data since we analyzed it in February. Here’s an update on those changes and what we hope to see next for the data.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Sara Simon works on The COVID Tracking Project’s data quality team and is also a contributing writer. She most recently worked as an investigative data reporter at Spotlight PA and software engineer at The New York Times.

blog_post.title: Inconsistent Reporting Practices Hampered Our Ability to Analyze COVID-19 Data. Here Are Three Common Problems We Identified.

lede.lede: With little consistency in how states defined, published, and presented COVID-19 data, it is difficult to compare situations across states.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Conor Kelly is the director of data analytics at Hanover Research.
Erin Kissane is a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the project’s managing editor.
Dave Luo has an MD/MBA and is a Data Science and Data Viz lead at The COVID Tracking Project.
Alexis C. Madrigal is a staff writer at The Atlantic, a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the author of Powering the Dream: The History and Promise of Green Technology.
Jessica Malaty Rivera has an MS in Emerging Infectious Diseases and is the Science Communication Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.
Peter Walker is Head of Marketing & Growth at PublicRelay and Data Viz Co-Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: A New Surge Has Arrived in Michigan, but We Don’t Know What It Will Look Like

lede.lede: According to federal data, COVID-19 cases and hospitalizations have reversed their decline in Michigan, marking a new surge concentrated in and around Detroit, but affecting regions statewide.

childMarkdownRemark.html: The COVID Tracking Project is a volunteer organization launched from The Atlantic and dedicated to collecting and publishing the data required to understand the COVID-19 outbreak in the United States.

blog_post.title: Releasing our Annotations on COVID-19 State Data Definitions

lede.lede: As part of our wind-down process, we’re publicly sharing our structured metadata on state COVID-19 data definitions.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Erin Kissane is a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the project’s managing editor.

blog_post.title: Where to Find Simple COVID-19 Data for the US

lede.lede: As The COVID Tracking Project approaches its final day of data compilation on March 7, 2021, we are recommending a selection of federal data sources to people who want a quick and easy way to keep an eye on the pandemic.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Erin Kissane is a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the project’s managing editor.
Alexis C. Madrigal is a staff writer at The Atlantic, a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the author of Powering the Dream: The History and Promise of Green Technology.

blog_post.title: Giving Thanks and Looking Ahead: Our Data Collection Work Is Done

lede.lede: While our work to compile COVID-19 data has concluded, we will continue to share research, analysis, and documentation in the months ahead. We are enormously grateful to the hundreds of volunteers who made this work possible.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Kara Schechtman is Data Quality Co-Lead for The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Federal COVID Data 101: Working with Testing Data

lede.lede: At least three different federal agencies share testing data for SARS-CoV-2 in at least four different places. Here’s a little about where that data comes from, what each dataset has to offer, and how you can use the datasets best in light of their large differences from state-provided data.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Hannah Hoffman is a data entry and data quality shift lead at The COVID Tracking Project and a student in the Washington, DC area.

blog_post.title: How Day-of-Week Effects Impact COVID-19 Data

lede.lede: An understanding of state reporting schedules and day-of-week effects can help explain the reasons that numbers fluctuate from day to day, and what those changes mean.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Kara Schechtman is Data Quality Co-Lead for The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Federal Testing Data’s Last Mile

lede.lede: Federal testing data is already more standardized and more detailed than the data we compile from states can ever be. But in some jurisdictions, state-provided data still provides a more comprehensive picture of testing volume. The federal government should address lingering quality problems so its data can become the national standard.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Kara Schechtman is Data Quality Co-Lead for The COVID Tracking Project.

Sara Simon works on The COVID Tracking Project’s data quality team and is also a contributing writer. She most recently worked as an investigative data reporter at Spotlight PA and software engineer at The New York Times.

blog_post.title: Silent Data Mismatches Are Compromising Key COVID-19 Indicators

lede.lede: Although we’d prefer to have precise, real-time, comprehensive COVID-19 data for every US state and territory, the reality is that every metric that each jurisdiction publishes comes with quirks of timing and content that can make precise calculations impossible.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Michael Parks is a journalist and communications specialist with a background in energy research and policy.
Nicole Rivera is a policy and public affairs professional who has focused on developing creative and strategic ways to communicate complex issues with clarity.

blog_post.title: Better COVID-19 Data Is Coming By August 1—But Will the Public See It?

lede.lede: Starting in August, new federal rules will require testing labs to report better data on the spread of COVID-19 in the United States. What happens to this new information is up to state and local officials. Journalists, open-data advocates, and members of the public can help us hold governments accountable for collecting and publishing this urgently needed data.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Erin Kissane is a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the project’s managing editor.
Jessica Malaty Rivera has an MS in Emerging Infectious Diseases and is the Science Communication Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.
Peter Walker is Head of Marketing & Growth at PublicRelay and Data Viz Co-Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: All Eyes on Hospitalizations: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Dec 30

lede.lede: Holiday reporting has garbled most metrics. Going by current COVID-19 hospitalizations, outbreaks in the Midwest are still easing, but every other region is in trouble.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Hannah Hoffman is a data entry and data quality shift lead at The COVID Tracking Project and a student in the Washington, DC area.

blog_post.title: How We Source Our Data and Why It Matters

lede.lede: States provide COVID-19 data in a variety of sources and formats. To ensure our data is as accurate and consistent as possible, we spend a lot of time looking at these sources to make sure that we’re capturing the most data possible for each state, while maintaining high standards of data quality and integrity. Today, we’re publicly releasing a detailed set of notes on the sources of all our data points.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Kara Schechtman is Data Quality Co-Lead for The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Counting COVID-19 Tests: How States Do It, How We Do It, and What’s Changing

lede.lede: Many states have moved toward greater transparency about their test data reporting methods, and we’re making changes to better represent what they publish. We’re also introducing a “new” way some states are counting tests—one we think all states and territories would be wise to embrace.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Júlia Ledur is a visual journalist and illustrator who leads the visualization team at The COVID Tracking Project. She is a former graphics reporter at Reuters.
Jessica Malaty Rivera has an MS in Emerging Infectious Diseases and is the Science Communication Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Test Types 101: The Pros and Cons of Different Approaches

lede.lede: Once limited to molecular tests, the United States now has other testing methods available. Their efficacy depends on multiple factors, including how far the person tested is in their infection and how high the test positivity is where they live.

childMarkdownRemark.html: The COVID Tracking Project is a volunteer organization launched from The Atlantic and dedicated to collecting and publishing the data required to understand the COVID-19 outbreak in the United States.

blog_post.title: Cases Matter

lede.lede: As COVID-19 cases rise across the United States, claims are circulating that case increases are (mostly or entirely) due to expanded testing, and do not indicate a spike in infections. The data does not support this conclusion.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Kara Schechtman is Data Quality Co-Lead for The COVID Tracking Project.
Michal Mart is Data Quality Co-Lead for The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Good News about Florida’s Testing Data

lede.lede: Florida is now publishing a full time series of test encounters, so we are picking up this metric in our API and on our website.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Erin Kissane is a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the project’s managing editor.

blog_post.title: Daily COVID-19 Data Is About to Get Weird

lede.lede: The upcoming holiday means that many COVID-19 metrics are going to drop—and then rise—in ways that may trip up unsuspecting observers. Here’s what to watch out for.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Whet Moser is a freelance writer in Chicago.

blog_post.title: What We Know About Covid Testing Sensitivity

lede.lede: To successfully manage the pandemic, we need tools for both surveillance and diagnosis, in the form of antigen tests and PCR tests.

childMarkdownRemark.html: The COVID Tracking Project is a volunteer organization launched from The Atlantic and dedicated to collecting and publishing the data required to understand the COVID-19 outbreak in the United States.

blog_post.title: Ultralight Recommendations for a National Pandemic Dashboard

lede.lede: The announcement of a forthcoming national pandemic dashboard is heartening news for COVID-19 data folks all over the country. We have a few modest suggestions for the team that will undertake this work.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Tong Wang is an MD-PhD candidate at the University of Pennsylvania.
Jessica Malaty Rivera has an MS in Emerging Infectious Diseases and is the Science Communication Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.
Júlia Ledur is a visual journalist and illustrator who leads the visualization team at The COVID Tracking Project. She is a former graphics reporter at Reuters.

blog_post.title: The Other COVID-19 Metric We Should Be Using

lede.lede: As exposure risk increases, so does the need for more testing. The more we test, the more cases we can identify—which is a good thing. But are we looking at the right metrics to know if we are performing enough tests?

childMarkdownRemark.html: Erin Kissane is a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the project’s managing editor.
Jessica Malaty Rivera has an MS in Emerging Infectious Diseases and is the Science Communication Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: It's Not Just Testing

lede.lede: As case counts surge, we look at regional and state-level numbers to find out which recent jumps in COVID-19 case counts are likely to be explained by increased testing, and which are not. For the states with the worst recent numbers, the news is not good.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Erin Kissane is a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the project’s managing editor.
Jessica Malaty Rivera has an MS in Emerging Infectious Diseases and is the Science Communication Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Test Positivity in the US Is a Mess

lede.lede: Interpreted correctly, test positivity can tell us so much that we need to know about COVID-19 outbreaks and testing in the United States. But we don’t publish test positivity calculations for US states and territories. Here’s why.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Betsy Ladyzhets is a Research Editor at Stacker and works on data quality and the COVID Racial Data Tracker at the COVID Tracking Project.
Quang P. Nguyen is a PhD candidate in the Department of Epidemiology at Dartmouth College.

blog_post.title: The State of State Antigen Test Reporting

lede.lede: Antigen tests are becoming a major tool for rapid COVID-19 testing. But if states don’t report results clearly, we won’t know the true impact of these tests.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Júlia Ledur is a visual journalist and illustrator who leads the visualization team at The COVID Tracking Project. She is a former graphics reporter at Reuters.
Jessica Malaty Rivera has an MS in Emerging Infectious Diseases and is the Science Communication Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.
Tong Wang is an MD-PhD candidate at the University of Pennsylvania.

blog_post.title: Test Positivity: So Valuable, So Easy to Misinterpret

lede.lede: Test positivity is extremely useful, but it has also become one of the most commonly misunderstood metrics for monitoring the COVID-19 pandemic. Here, we take a step back and look at what it really means.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Erin Kissane is a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the project’s managing editor.
Peter Walker is Head of Marketing & Growth at PublicRelay and Data Viz Co-Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Testing In Limbo, Hospitalizations and Deaths Still Dropping: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Sep 10

lede.lede: A long holiday weekend makes ambiguous testing data even harder to understand, but hospitalizations are dropping, which is good.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Joanna Pearlstein is an editorial lead at the Covid Tracking Project and a former editor at WIRED and Protocol.
Peter Walker is Head of Marketing & Growth at PublicRelay and Data Viz Co-Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Holiday Reporting Lags Interrupt Positive Trends: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Sep 17

lede.lede: Though cases are rising in parts of the Midwest, hospitalizations in the West and South continued trending downward. The Labor Day holiday impacted data reporting lag times both this week and last, obscuring what had been positive trends in September.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Erin Kissane is a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the project’s managing editor.
Peter Walker is Head of Marketing & Growth at PublicRelay and Data Viz Co-Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.
Rebecca Glassman has a Master’s in Public Health and is a public health researcher in academia. Opinions expressed are her own.

blog_post.title: Cases Stop Dropping and the Midwest Heats Up: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Sep 3

lede.lede: After five straight weeks of sharp declines in new cases of COVID-19 in the United States, we’ve leveled off again. Reported tests are up about 5 percent, but are actually dropping in the Midwest, where three states—Iowa, North Dakota, and South Dakota—are driving an uptick in new cases. This week we also launched a new dataset that looks closely at the toll of COVID-19 in nursing homes and other long-term care facilities.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Conor Kelly is the director of data analytics at Hanover Research.
Judith Oppenheim works on Texas City Data and state outreach at The COVID Tracking Project.
Pat Kelly is a technology executive and entrepreneur based in Austin, Texas, and works on The COVID Racial Data Tracker and The Long-Term Care COVID Tracker at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Something Is Wrong with Testing Data in the Great State of Texas

lede.lede: According to the official state numbers, COVID-19 testing has dropped dramatically in August. However, county-level statistics show the opposite story. What’s going on?

childMarkdownRemark.html: Alexis C. Madrigal is a staff writer at The Atlantic, a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the author of Powering the Dream: The History and Promise of Green Technology.
Peter Walker is Head of Marketing & Growth at PublicRelay and Data Viz Co-Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Tests, Cases, and Hospitalizations Keep Dropping: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Aug 13

lede.lede: Testing continues to fall, especially in the South, one of the areas where the country needs it the most. Cases, too, are falling, which remains hard to interpret, given the testing decline—but fewer people are now in the hospital with COVID-19 than last week. This is the second week in a row that hospitalizations seem to have dropped, which suggests that infections may be declining independently of testing reductions.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Júlia Ledur is a visual journalist and illustrator who leads the visualization team at The COVID Tracking Project. She is a former graphics reporter at Reuters.
Emma Rubin is a recent college graduate and freelance journalist.

blog_post.title: Florida’s Per-Capita COVID-19 Cases Just Surpassed New York’s, but Are the Two Outbreaks Comparable? Yes and No.

lede.lede: Florida has reported over 461,000 total COVID-19 cases, surpassing New York for the highest per-capita caseload in the United States—but a simple comparison doesn’t represent the critical differences in the data we have for the two outbreaks.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Jessica Malaty Rivera has an MS in Emerging Infectious Diseases and is the Science Communication Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.
Alice Goldfarb leads The COVID Tracking Project’s part in The COVID Racial Data Tracker, and is a Nieman Visiting Fellow.

blog_post.title: Record New Cases, Surging Hospitalizations, Rising Deaths: This Week in COVID-19 Data, July 9

lede.lede: The South continues to be the epicenter of surges in both cases and hospitalizations. In Arizona, Florida, South Carolina, and Texas, COVID-19 deaths have begun to climb following jumps in new cases. And for the first time since April, deaths are rising nationally.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Erin Kissane is a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the project’s managing editor.
Alexis C. Madrigal is a staff writer at The Atlantic, a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the author of Powering the Dream: The History and Promise of Green Technology.

blog_post.title: This Week in COVID-19 Data, July 2: Across the US, Outbreaks Are Catching Fire

lede.lede: The US has broken its record for new COVID-19 cases three times in the last week. Thirteen states broke their new-case records since Sunday. In the states with the worst outbreaks, hospitalizations and deaths are rising.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Erin Kissane is a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the project’s managing editor.
Peter Walker is Head of Marketing & Growth at PublicRelay and Data Viz Co-Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Weekly COVID-19 Data Update, June 25: The US Pandemic Is Surging in the South and West

lede.lede: The United States hit a record high for new COVID-19 cases this week. In many areas with rising case counts, testing isn’t keeping up. Meanwhile, hospitalizations in regions with big outbreaks are increasing.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Jessica Malaty Rivera has an MS in Emerging Infectious Diseases and is the Science Communication Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.
Peter Walker is Head of Marketing & Growth at PublicRelay and Data Viz Co-Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Weekly COVID-19 Data Update, June 18: The Regional Gap Widens

lede.lede: As cases and hospitalizations continue to drop in the early Northeast epicenters, they are rising—in some areas quite sharply—in the South and West. We look at the numbers and at the relationship between an increase in tests and a rise in case counts.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Peter Walker is Head of Marketing & Growth at PublicRelay and Data Viz Co-Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.
Erin Kissane is a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the project’s managing editor.

blog_post.title: Weekly COVID-19 Data Update, June 11: Early Data from May Transmission

lede.lede: The news this week is mixed and highly regional. In the early US epicenter of the outbreak, cases continue to drop. In the southern and western United States, cases are on the rise, as are COVID-19 hospitalizations. And as always, the lag makes the data difficult to put into context.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Erin Kissane is a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the project’s managing editor.
Quang P. Nguyen is a PhD candidate in the Department of Epidemiology at Dartmouth College.

blog_post.title: What Is a Probable Case of COVID-19?

lede.lede: Probable cases of COVID-19 make up only a small fraction of currently reported cases, but the CDC wants states to do a better job reporting them. So what are they and why do they matter? We took a closer look to help reporters and members of the public better understand this complex COVID-19 metric.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Jessica Malaty Rivera has an MS in Emerging Infectious Diseases and is the Science Communication Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.
Amber Wojcek is a B2B marketing director in Sanford, Florida, and a contributor to The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Tracking the States and the CDC

lede.lede: For months, we've worked to patch together inconsistent state-reported data into a national set of numbers for COVID-19 case, death, and testing in the US. The CDC has now published a COVID Data Tracker, but their data only partially matches the numbers we get from the state public health authorities. So we took a closer look.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Quang P. Nguyen is a PhD candidate in the Department of Epidemiology at Dartmouth College.
Erin Kissane is a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the project’s managing editor.

blog_post.title: Position Statement on Antibody Data Reporting

lede.lede: As antibody tests become more widely available across the United States, we call on all states and territories to preserve the integrity and usefulness of their COVID-19 testing data by maintaining separate viral testing and antibody testing counts.

About half of states report two different types of positive cases: “lab-confirmed” cases and “probable cases.” The difference between the two types is important, but we continue to see questions about what a probable case actually is—and why reporting them matters. ","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommend that states separate their data into lab-confirmed and probable cases. For six states that report them separately, however—Colorado, Delaware, Idaho, Maine, Michigan, and Wisconsin—","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"probable cases make up between eight and 12 percent of all cases","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":". In ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"Wyoming, more than 20 percent of all known cases are probable cases","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":", and in ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"Puerto Rico, that figure is more than 75 percent","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":". We would, therefore, expect the proportion of probable cases to rise nationally as more states either begin to report them or to label them correctly. ","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"At The COVID Tracking Project, ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"our “cases” metric","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://covidtracking.com/data"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" currently includes both lab-confirmed and probable cases in a single figure, but we’ve been internally tracking probable cases separately for states that publish them. We suspect that some states publish a case count that lumps probable and lab-confirmed cases, but this has been difficult to verify. Our data team is reengineering our API and spreadsheets to include probable case metrics where we have them. However, until all states publish and clearly label probable and lab-confirmed cases—or verify that their case data counts only lab-confirmed cases—our case count will necessarily mix the two kinds of cases. ","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"But what exactly is a probable case? To get there, we first need to define the other kind of COVID-19 case: “lab-confirmed.”","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"heading-3","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"What’s a lab-confirmed COVID-19 case?","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"A lab-confirmed case is a person whose illness has been diagnosed as COVID-19 using an FDA approved test that meets the standards set out in the ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"April 5, 2020 Interim Case Definition for COVID-19","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://wwwn.cdc.gov/nndss/conditions/coronavirus-disease-2019-covid-19/case-definition/2020/"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" developed by the ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Council for State and Territorial Epidemiologists","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://www.cste.org/"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":". The case definition says that cases of COVID-19 are confirmed by a particular kind of test—“molecular amplification”—that can detect viral RNA.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"There are two approved tests of this kind in broad use in the United States. The most common is the RT-PCR test. RT-PCR stands for “real-time polymerase chain reaction,” and the Mayo Clinic’s research magazine offers ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"an excellent primer on the science behind the test","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://discoverysedge.mayo.edu/2020/03/27/the-science-behind-the-test-for-the-covid-19-virus/"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":". RT-PCR is currently the gold standard for infectious disease molecular diagnostics. ","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"The other molecular amplification test used in the US is the more controversial Abbott ID-NOW test. The molecular amplification and RNA detection methods used in this test differ slightly from the RT-PCR test. It produces results within about fifteen minutes—significantly less than the four to five hours required by the RT-PCR test. But, this test has proven to be less reliable, so the FDA ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"weighs","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://www.fda.gov/media/136522/download"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" its positive and negative results differently: A positive result from an Abbott ID-NOW test is considered lab confirmation of COVID-19, but a negative result is considered only “presumptive.” In plain language, this means that if a patient with symptoms of COVID-19 receives a negative result from the Abbott ID-NOW test, they should also be given an RT-PCR test to verify the result.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"To recap, someone with a lab-confirmed case of COVID-19 doesn’t have to show symptoms or have an exposure to a known case. They just need a positive result from one of the approved tests.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"heading-3","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"What’s a probable COVID-19 case?","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"The definition of a probable case is a bit more complicated. In the absence of a confirmatory lab test, public-health experts can piece together other evidence of infection to try to identify cases that are very likely to be COVID-19 and exclude cases that only ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"might","marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" be COVID-19. The job of deciding what counts as a probable case falls, again, to the Council of State and Territorial Epidemiologists.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"The CSTE’s ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Interim Case Definition for COVID-19","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://wwwn.cdc.gov/nndss/conditions/coronavirus-disease-2019-covid-19/case-definition/2020/"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" defines a probable case of COVID-19 as one that meets one of three sets of requirements: ","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"unordered-list","content":[{"nodeType":"list-item","content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Meet clinical criteria AND epidemiologic evidence with no confirmatory laboratory testing performed for COVID-19.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"list-item","content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Meet presumptive laboratory evidence AND either clinical criteria OR epidemiologic evidence.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"list-item","content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Meet vital records criteria with no confirmatory laboratory testing performed for COVID-19.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Requirements in the case definition refer to four kinds of information used to pinpoint COVID-19 infections: ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"clinical criteria","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":", ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"epidemiologic evidence","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":", ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"presumptive laboratory evidence","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":", and ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"vital records criteria","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":". Let’s take a closer look at those.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Four classes of information that can establish a probable case of COVID-19:","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"unordered-list","content":[{"nodeType":"list-item","content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"“Clinical criteria”","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" refers to sets of COVID-19 specific symptoms and scan results (which are listed in the official CSTE ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"case definition","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://cdn.ymaws.com/www.cste.org/resource/resmgr/2020ps/Interim-20-ID-01_COVID-19.pdf"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" and on the CDC ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"website","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/symptoms-testing/symptoms.html"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":") that must be present.  However, ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"clinical criteria are not met","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" unless there is ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"also","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" “no alternative more likely diagnosis.” For some symptoms—cough, shortness of breath, or difficulty breathing—having one along with no alternative more likely diagnosis is enough to meet the standard of evidence for clinical criteria. For many other symptoms, including fever, sore throat, or loss of smell or taste, a suspected case must present at least two symptoms on the list, along with no alternative more likely diagnosis.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"list-item","content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"“Epidemiologic evidence”","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" refers to whether a patient has been in close contact with someone with COVID-19 or has traveled to an area with sustained, ongoing community transmission. Contact tracing and travel histories provide this evidence.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"list-item","content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"“Presumptive laboratory evidence”","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" refers to the results of antibody (serology) and antigen testing. (Remember, only molecular amplification detection tests that look for viral presence in samples can provide confirmatory laboratory evidence).","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"list-item","content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"“Vital records criteria”","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" refers to death certificates that list COVID-19 or SARS-CoV–2 as a cause of death or a significant condition contributing to death. Cause-of-death determination is another area with nested sets of criteria. The CDC provides ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"detailed guidance","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://www.cdc.gov/nchs/covid19/coding-and-reporting.htm"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" on when and how to list COVID-19 as a cause of death or significant condition contributing to death, and some states like Colorado have provided more specific ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"death counts","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://covid19.colorado.gov/data/case-data"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" beyond the vital records criteria. This is a complex topic that we’ll discuss further in a future post.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"These criteria can interact in surprising ways. Here are some of the paths by which someone could be found to have a probable case of COVID-19:","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"unordered-list","content":[{"nodeType":"list-item","content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Someone who has difficulty breathing AND no alternative more likely diagnosis (clinical criteria) AND has been in close contact with someone who has COVID-19 (epidemiologic evidence) is considered a probable case (unless or until they receive a test that counts as confirmatory).","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"list-item","content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Someone who has traveled to a known COVID-19 hotspot and then has a positive antibody test result is considered a probable case.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"list-item","content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Someone whose death certificate lists COVID-19 as a cause of death or significant condition contributing to death, but who did not receive a molecular amplification detection test is considered a probable case.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"On the other hand, some suspected cases that may well be COVID-19 infections don’t meet the criteria to be considered a probable case. For example:","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"unordered-list","content":[{"nodeType":"list-item","content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Someone who gets a positive antigen or antibody test result is not considered a probable case unless they also show specific clinical or epidemiologic evidence.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"list-item","content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Someone with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) and no alternative more likely diagnosis (clinical criteria) is not considered to be a probable case unless they have an additional positive antigen or antibody test OR  epidemiologic evidence.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"list-item","content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Someone who shares a room with a person with lab-confirmed COVID-19 and who has unexplained loss of smell or taste and no other symptoms is not considered to be a probable case unless they have an additional positive antigen or antibody test.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"The “probable” case criteria are quite strict by design. People who have COVID-19 but aren’t yet symptomatic—or who don’t ever develop noticeable symptoms—wouldn’t meet the clinical criteria. Because of uneven access to testing that would provide lab evidence and a lack of comprehensive contact tracing that could provide epidemiologic evidence, we can conclude that many actual COVID-19 infections do not meet the criteria to be reported as either lab-confirmed or probable cases. That’s not a bad thing; the definition is built to exclude all but the likeliest cases. But it’s useful to keep in mind that even probable case counts are likely to miss many infections. ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"In other words, many people who have actual COVID-19 infections are not considered to be probable COVID-19 cases.","marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"heading-3","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Why it’s important to count probable cases","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"First, it’s what the experts want. On April 5,  the Council for State and Territorial Epidemiologists ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"recommended","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://docs.google.com/document/d/1YoNfoFbEypTs3Fczdm6B4vkwJbkdcHGuN7LJ1ycbkVU/edit#"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" that both confirmed and probable cases of COVID-19 should be “included in the ‘case’ count released outside of the public health agency.” The council also said that the CDC should publish both metrics. The CDC, in turn, began including probables in its ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"online case counts","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://www.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#cases"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":". ","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Second, it provides more context for coronavirus data. Some CDC officials have expressed concern that current case counts from states are too low. In a June 8th article in ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"The Washington Post","marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":", CDC spokeswoman Kristen Nordlund stated that “the current case and deaths counts reported to CDC are likely an undercount.” Sources ranging from ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"public health researchers and officials","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/05/22/us/politics/coronavirus-trump-death-toll.html"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" to ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Goldman Sachs analysts","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://ca.finance.yahoo.com/news/the-us-may-be-undercounting-covid-19-cases-by-a-massive-margin-goldman-sachs-warns-181503102.html"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" have also repeatedly ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"expressed the belief ","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2020/05/13/854873605/fauci-says-u-s-death-toll-is-likely-higher-other-covid-stats-need-adjusting-too"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" that official US data undercounts actual COVID-19 cases. ","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"If more states included their official probable cases, the United States would still be ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"unlikely to completely close the gap between the data and the reality","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jamainternalmedicine/fullarticle/2766121?guestAccessKey=cb171e02-ae9a-4f40-97d4-a69dc439a904&utm_source=For_The_Media&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=ftm_links&utm_content=tfl&utm_term=051420"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":", but its sense of the pandemic would improve. Nevertheless, many state health departments have failed to provide data on probable cases to the CDC, or to the public—and not always for clear reasons. In a press conference on June 10th, Indiana’s State Health Commissioner responded to a question about why Indiana was not following the CDC’s guidelines on reporting probable cases by stating that “We, just like most states, do not report that and we don’t report it on our website. There is no particular reason for that.”","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"In a response to ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"The Washington Post","marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://www.washingtonpost.com/investigations/cdc-wants-states-to-count-probable-coronavirus-cases-and-deaths-but-most-arent-doing-it/2020/06/07/4aac9a58-9d0a-11ea-b60c-3be060a4f8e1_story.html"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":", North Carolina’s state health department cited concerns about the reliability of antibody tests (even though antibody tests do not, on their own, provide evidence for a probable case) and “concerns that the CSTE’s definition of a probable case is overly broad.”","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"In the same ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"Washington Post","marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" report on probable cases, officials in the District of Columbia, ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"which had counted 9,799 confirmed cases of COVID-19 as of June 15","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://covidtracking.com/data/state/district-of-columbia"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":", claimed that they hadn’t reported probable cases to the CDC because they didn’t have any. For comparison, Delaware, ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"which had reported 9,378 confirmed cases of COVID-19 as of the same date","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://coronavirus.delaware.gov/"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":", ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"has reported nearly 1,000 probable cases","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://www.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/index.html#cases"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":". ","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Until states report both confirmed and probable cases in accordance with CDC guidelines and the CSTE’s case definition, public health officials, researchers, journalists, and the public all lose valuable opportunities to compare outbreaks across regions.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

lede.lede: Probable cases of COVID-19 make up only a small fraction of currently reported cases, but the CDC wants states to do a better job reporting them. So what are they and why do they matter? We took a closer look to help reporters and members of the public better understand this complex COVID-19 metric.
